feed.title: Combined summary - BIP CPRKV: Check private key verify

entry.title: Combined summary - BIP CPRKV: Check private key verify
entry.summary: The email conversations among Bitcoin developers in 2016 explored various proposals and solutions related to altcoins, cross-chain transfers, and Lightning Network. One of the discussions involved creating a new opcode for an altcoin, but it was later determined that the altcoin would only accept standard output scripts. The focus then shifted to maintaining standard scripts on the altcoin.Another discussion focused on using CLTV for cross-chain transfers, but many altcoins do not support CLTV, making transfers insecure. To address this issue, Tier Nolan created a BIP draft for an opcode that would lock outputs unless a private key matching a given public key was published. However, it may require specific support in the altcoin, which could be troublesome.In addition to these discussions, there were proposals to remove certain opcodes and use alternative methods such as cut and choose or non-standard scripts. For example, one proposal involved increasing the sigop count for a NOP without using segwit, allowing the Bitcoin network to act as a trusted third party so that channels can be safely used on the altcoin, despite its malleability issues and lack of OP_CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY.Another proposed solution was to remove the OP_CHECKPRIVPUBPAIR opcode and instead use OP_CAT and OP_CHECKSIGVERIFY. This proposal involves two parties agreeing upon a random secret nonce, k, and calculating r in the same way as signing a transaction. The proposal is deemed useful for lightning network, but segregated witness is likely to take priority for soft-fork slot usage.Tier Nolan also proposed another BIP CPRKV, Check Private Key Verify, via bitcoin-dev mailing list to address the issue of using CLTV for cross-chain transfers. The proposed protocol uses cut and choose to allow commitments to publish private keys, but it is considered clunky and not entirely secure. The protocol includes four steps where Bob trades b Bitcoins for altcoins with Alice. It is available on GitHub, and the email sender ensured that their computer was virus-free and protected by Avast.
